Explain what is meant by a "connection gap" in the context of highways

A "connection gap" in highway terminology refers to a perceived absence of a connection between two segments of a highway that are actually linked through unsigned interstate route segments or other local roads, without internal unsigned concurrencies on other interstate highway segments between the parent route and signed terminus.

Elaborate on the concept of 'true gaps' in the context of the Interstate Highway System.

True gaps in the Interstate Highway System refer to instances where multiple disjointed sections of the same Interstate highway share the same number, and can be considered as part of 'one highway' in theory due to their geographical proximity, connection via other highways, or future plans to fill the gap. These gaps occur when sections are not physically connected or if they are connected but not officially recognized as part of the Interstate highway.

Explain the concept of a barrier transfer machine on bridges and how it is used in interstate highways.

A barrier transfer machine on bridges is a system used in some interstate highways to convert inner lanes from one direction to the other. It is used on bridges where it would be too costly to upgrade or rebuild to a higher-capacity bridge. The machine manipulates a flexible Jersey barrier to adjust the traffic distribution on the bridge depending on the time of day.

What are the characteristics of true gaps in the Interstate Highway system?

True gaps in the Interstate Highway system refer to multiple disjoint sections of road with the same Interstate highway number, which can be considered as one highway in theory. These sections are either not physically connected at all, or connected but not signed as part of the highway. The gaps can be due to unconnected segments of the same route or from failure of the road to fully conform to Interstate standards, including features like at-grade crossings, traffic lights, undivided or narrow freeways, or movable bridges.

Explain the concept of a true gap in the Interstate Highway System.

A true gap in the Interstate Highway System emerges when two or more disjoint sections host the same Interstate highway number, despite having no physical connection or a connection not signed as part of the highway. These gaps may be due to reasons like incomplete conformance to Interstate standards or future plans to fill the gap. Common characteristics include at-grade crossings, traffic lights, undivided or narrow freeways, or movable bridges.
